oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bridging the gap between reality and simulations : an ethernet case study
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: RATHOD, P
PERUR, S
RANGARAJAN, R
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Simulation is a widely used technique in networking research and a practice that has suffered loss of credibility in recent years due to doubts about its reliability. In this paper we conduct a simple Ethernet experiment on a test-bed, and try to reproduce the results using three popular network simulators: ns-2, QualNet and OPNET Modeler We find that after careful simulation we are able to approximate test-bed performance in all three simulators, and we document the simulation process for each one. We also identify blocking socket calls as a behavioral attribute of applications that affects performance, but cannot be set in any of the three simulators used.
